Beautiful Font Rendering on Debian

tags: linux, debian, fonts
When I switched over from Ubuntu to Debian, I often used to wonder why the fonts were not rendered by Debian as beautifully as Ubuntu did. Still it was usable, so I did not bother much. The question haunted me again when I ditched the Gnome Dekstop Environment in favor of Awesome Window Manager. Font rendering had deteriorated so much that long sessions had become totally impossible. Then I discovered this ".fonts.conf" file which made the font rendering on my Debian box as good as that of Ubuntu.



The contents of this gist goes in a ".fonts.conf" file in your home directory. You will probably have to restart your X server for the effects to take place.

May 15, 2010

NeXML I/O, and, RDF triples API for BioRuby

tags: ruby, rdf, nexml, phylosoc, gsoc2010
Ruby and Google Summer of Code. Pure fun. My job is to add NeXML parsing and serializing support, and an RDF triples API to BioRuby.

NeXML is a file format, based on XML, to express Phylogenetic data. Phylogenetics is the study of evolutionary relatedness among various groups of organisms. Evolution is a branching process wherein a new species evolves from the existing populace. Evolutionary relatedness between such species can be studied by DNA sequence analysis( and some other methods ). This can be visualized as a tree, the phylogenetic tree. Naturally, phylogenetic data will involve working with a set of species, a tree to depict their evolutionary relatedness and how such relations have been inferred.

RDF( or, Resource Description Framework ) is a meta data model. Conceptually, you use RDF to assert relation between, a subject and an object using a predicate. Say, the colour of my car is black. RDF breaks the previous assertion into (subject, predicate, object) => (car, color, black), also called triples. Phylogenetic database by nature is huge and complex. To find the relevant information efficiently, it is necessary to index phylogenetic data with descriptive information( or, meta data ).

The project has been offered under National Evolutionary Synthesis Center( NESCENT ). I will be mentored by Dr. Rutger Vos (primary), and Dr. Jan Aerts.

Coding starts from 24th May. Interested souls might find the "phylosoc" label on this blog and the project wiki[1] interesting.

Links:-
  1. Project Wiki
  2. Source Code
  3. Other accepted projects from NESCENT


Apr 14, 2010

Seamlessly use Github behind http proxy on port 443

tags: linux, debian, git, github, proxy
This works if you proxy allows connection on port 443( used for https ). Open up ~/.ssh/config and enter the following lines( appropriately filling in values for proxy_host and proxy_port ):

Host gitproxy
User git
HostName ssh.github.com
Port 443
ProxyCommand corkscrew proxy_host proxy_port %h %p
IdentityFile /home/yeban/.ssh/id_rsa

Now, if your repository URL is git@github.com:username/test.git, you would use it as git@gitproxy:username/test.git

Courtsey: http://blog.codeslower.com/2008/8/Using-PuTTY-and-SSL-to-securely-access-GitHub-repositories-via-SSH

Update:
In the Host section, if you put github.com instead of gitproxy, then you can use your repository's git url unaltered.

Apr 11, 2010

Use Gmail to send emails from Ruby script

tags: ruby, gmail, programming
Here is a very simple script to send emails from a Ruby script with your Gmail account.
Feel free to add your own modifications and use it as you like. I used a modified version of the script to send mail to all the people registered to one of my college clubs.

Observations:
  1. Ruby 1.8.7 lacks the support for TLS; used 'tlsmail' gem to remedy this.
  2. The msg local variable holds both: the email header and the email body, separated by a LF('\n')
  3. The SMTP library automatically converts a single occurrence of a CR('\r') or LF('\n') to a CRLF pair.
  4. If you miss out on the header, Gmail won't show much details when you click on "show details"
  5. The message will be send even if the from_email part is missing in the sendmail fucntion.
Links:
  1. A Rubyesque interface to Gmail - I have not tried it yet, but the features look promising.
  2. Rdoc for Ruby net/smtp library.
